title: Residual Speech Embeddings for Tone Classification: Removing Linguistic Content to Enhance Paralinguistic Analysis
author: Hamdan Al Ahbabi (Khalifa University), Gautier Marti (ADIA), Saeed AlMarri (Khalifa University), Ibrahim Elfadel (Khalifa University), ...
relevance_why: The technique of using residual embeddings to separate linguistic from paralinguistic information is relevant to Haohe Liu’s interests in audio processing, particularly in sentiment analysis and speech restoration.
background: The paper explores how to improve tone classification in speech by separating the non-verbal tone from the verbal content using self-supervised learning techniques.
contribution: This paper introduces residual embeddings to solve the issue of mixing linguistic and paralinguistic features in speech embeddings, achieving enhanced tone classification performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods have struggled with entangling speech content and prosody, typically maintaining both linguistic and paralinguistic features in one vector.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work proposes a regression-based method to extract residual embeddings that focus solely on tone, improving classification accuracy significantly.

key_innovation: The method specifically regresses speech embeddings on text embeddings to discretely capture tone characteristics while removing any linguistic meaning.
real_world_impact: This technique could improve various applications in AI-driven speech analysis, including sentiment detection and speaker characterization, ultimately aiding in the creation of more intuitive conversational agents.

new_terms.residual embeddings: **Residual embeddings** refer to the portion of the embeddings that capture information not explained by the linguistic content, focusing on prosodic and paralinguistic features.
